docs.lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, medical laboratory companies were as sick as many of the patients whose blood and urine they tested. The business was rife with overbilling and fraud. Managed health care companies were restricting the number of tests patients could have and the fees paid for them. Virtually every medical laboratory company was losing money.

headline.main: A Positive Culture For Making Profits; Buoyed by Mergers, Medical Labs Await Era of Gene Testing

docs.abstract: Medical laboratory industry, which has consolidated, leaving two giants, Quest Diagnostics and Laboratory Corp of America Holdings, is awaiting era of gene testing; analysts say first medical payoffs from genomics will not be drugs but diagnostic tests; start-up companies like diaDexus and Exact Sciences, as well as established companies like Applied BioSystems, are developing molecular diagnostics, term for gene and protein testing; they hope that patent protection for genes will allow them to charge higher prices for their tests than in past; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The rate of teenage pregnancy in the United States in 1997 dropped to its lowest level in 20 years, new figures from the National Center for Health Statistics at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show. Teenage pregnancy dropped 19 percent from its peak in 1990, to 94.3 pregnancies per thousand teenagers from 116.5. The decline was attributed to increased use of condoms and implantable contraceptives, as well as a leveling-off in sexual activity. The figures cover 1990 to 1997, the latest years for which complete data is available. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Teenage Pregnancy Rate Falls

docs.abstract: National Center for Health Statistics at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports rate of teenage pregnancy in US in 1997 dropped to lowest level in 20 years (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first court ruling on the issue of gender equity in drug coverage, a federal judge in Seattle said yesterday that the Bartell Drug Company, a family-owned drugstore chain, discriminated against women when it excluded prescription contraceptives from its employee health plan. The class-action lawsuit, filed last July by Jennifer Erickson, a 27-year- old pharmacist at Bartell, said the health insurance coverage violated the Pregnancy Discrimination Act by paying for all the basic health care needs of male employees while leaving female employees to pay for contraception.

headline.main: Judge Says Some Employers Must Cover Contraceptives

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Robert S Lasnik rules in Seattle that Bartell Drug Company, family-owned chain, discriminated against women in exclusing prescription contraceptives from employee health benefit plan; class-action lawsuit filed by pharmacist Jennifer Erickson charged violations of Pregnancy Discrimination Act by paying for all basic health needs of male employees while leaving women to pay for contraception; she and Planned Parenthood lawyer Roberta Riley welcome summary ruling; photo; company adds coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Devices and Desires: A History of Contraceptives in America,'' by Andrea Tone, Hill and Wang, $30. In 1992, Dr. Andrea Tone was finishing her dissertation at Emory University in Atlanta and volunteering at the Feminist Women's Health Center. While her academic labors focused on the history of industry, her work at the clinic provided an entirely different kind of food for thought, and eventually for research.

headline.main: Birth Control, From 'Womb Veils' to Lysol

docs.lead_paragraph: In Greek myth, Icarus flew too close to the sun and crashed when its heat melted the wax that held his wings together. That idea seems quaint, but now some scientists think the Greeks may have been right to fear flying too close to the sun. The problem is not the sun's heat, but the ionizing radiation it emits. For the last few months the sun has been at or near the peak of its ''storm'' season, when the solar wind, a thin but steady stream of protons that flows by at a gentle million miles an hour or so, is supplemented by bursts of protons moving at nearly the speed of light.

headline.main: The Frequent Flier And Radiation Risk

docs.abstract: Airline passengers flying at high altitude are exposed to ionizing radiation emitted by sun when sun is near or at peak of its 'storm' season; there is no evidence so far that this exposure is dangerous, but some crew members who fly polar routes for years can accumulate doses that are large relative to those received by nuclear power plant workers and oters who are conventionally thought to be 'radiation workers'; Northwest and Continental Airlines sometimes reroute polar flights, both to avoid solar storms and to avoid seasonal headwinds at lower latitudes; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What do stock analysts know about medical research? Last month Wall Street got nervous about the safety of two of the hottest prescription drugs on the market, Celebrex and Vioxx, after a company-sponsored study suggested that they might increase susceptibility to heart attacks. The two are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs that greatly reduce the risk of ulcers associated with older over-the-counter and prescription rivals, ibuprofen (Advil and Motrin), naproxen (Aleve and Naprosyn), indomethacin (Indocin) and aspirin.

headline.main: Newest Pain Killers Deserve a Closer Look

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on concerns about safety of two nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, Celebrex, made by Pharmacia, and Vioxx, made by Merck, after study suggested that they might increase susceptibility to heart attacks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The headline of a June 4 editorial reads ''Confusion on Affirmative Action,'' but there should be no confusion. Racial preferences are anathema. The people of California and Washington State affirmed this when they voted to prohibit discrimination. In education, the issue boils down to diversity versus the Constitution. Do universities have the right to infringe on a citizen's right to equal protection under the law in order to achieve racial diversity?

headline.main: Ways to Define A Diverse Campus

docs.lead_paragraph: A privately financed Dutch ship, equipped to carry out abortions in international waters near countries where the procedure is banned, is ready to set sail from here on its first voyage on Monday. The 130-foot ship, called Women on Waves, has a small operating room on board and a medical team of two doctors and a nurse. Its captain is a woman. The only men among the 10 crew members are the engineer and first mate.

headline.main: Dutch Ship Offers Abortions; To Make Ireland Its First Call

docs.abstract: Privately financed Dutch ship, equipped to carry out abortions in international waters near countries where procedure is banned, will set sail from Rotterdam, Netherlands, on June 11 on its first voyage; has small operating room on board and medical team of two doctors and nurse; first port of call will be Dublin, Ireland, where all abortion is illegal; only two of its 10 crew members are men; captain is woman; antiabortion groups in Dublin vow to stage protests (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Europe, when princes and princesses choose the wrong mate or just act beastly to each other or to common folk, the citizenry can always shrug and say, Well, the pomp and palaces bring in tourist dollars, so what's the harm? Not so in Asia. For many Asians living under the rule of kings, constitutional or not, royalty can be a mystically personal thing. So it was for the Nepalis who shaved their heads in mourning last week and rioted in disbelief that their crown prince, descendant of a god, could have slaughtered most of the royal family and then killed himself. Hundreds of other Nepalis waited in line outside the walls of the royal palace just to pay respects to a king who probably did nothing to make their starkly poor lives better.

headline.main: The World; Where Kings Still Matter

docs.abstract: For many Asians living under rule of kings, constitutional or not, royalty can be a mystically personal thing; horrific events in Nepal reviewed; royal family intrigues in other Asian nations, including Thailand and Cambodia, discussed; photo (M)
